author: By Sarah Bahr
title: With a Beloved Cafe Threatened, Broadway Stars Put on a Show
description: Fans in the theater world, including Matthew Broderick and Debra Messing, will appear in a Christmas Day telethon to try to save the West Bank Cafe.
content: When Tom D’Angora got the news that the West Bank Cafe — a popular show business hangout whose basement theater hosted the first “Sunday in the Park With George” rehearsals and Joan Rivers’s final performance — was in danger of closing, he sprang into action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Franklin
title: House Hunting in South Africa: A Mountainside Perch for $760,000
description: Reduced interest rates and transfer duties are luring buyers back to the housing market in South Africa, but the path to recovery remains rocky.
content: This four-bedroom house sits at the foot of the Skoorsteenberg peaks in Hout Bay, a coastal suburb of Cape Town, South Africa, where hikers and mountain climbers flock for views of the valley below and the Atlantic Ocean on the horizon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: How Mink, Like Humans, Were Slammed by the Coronavirus
description: Rampaging infections at farms caused scandal, scientific head-scratching and a search for a vaccine — for mink.
content: Denmark’s mink industry is gone, a victim of the coronavirus. The nation killed all its 17 million mink because of fears of a mutation in the virus that had spread from mink to people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: West Point Cheating Scandal: What to Know
description: More than 70 West Point cadets  have been accused of cheating on an exam, the institution's largest academic scandal in decades.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Helen Petersen
title: Are You Sure You Want to Go Back to the Office?
description: The future of work is flexibility.
content: There’s a common refrain among people who’ve been marooned in their homes this year, trying to manage their jobs and their children’s distance learning, always fighting the losing battle against the dishes, the laundry, the dog hair, the grocery list. “I cannot wait to get back to the office,” they say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba
title: Pennsylvania man is accused of casting Trump vote for his dead mother.
description: The Trump campaign had circulated the mother’s name while arguing there was widespread voter fraud that helped propel Joseph R. Biden Jr. to victory.
content: Shortly after the November election, the Trump campaign circulated on its Facebook and Twitter accounts, as well as its website, the names of seven dead Americans in the battleground states of Georgia and Pennsylvania. The dead people were used to cast votes in last month’s election, the campaign claimed, pointing to the incidents as evidence of widespread voter fraud that enabled President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas and Rebecca Robbins
title: Covid Antibody Drugs Go Unused as Need Soars
description: While such treatments are promising, their use has been slowed by testing lags, overwhelmed hospitals and a perception the therapies are only for well-connected people.
content: When federal regulators approved two antibody treatments last month for emergency use in high-risk Covid-19 patients, doctors worried there would not be enough to go around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Tiffany May
title: No Tweets, No Interviews: Jimmy Lai’s Unusual Bail Conditions
description: The Hong Kong pro-democracy media tycoon is freed on bail, but was placed under house arrest and barred from meeting foreign officials and publishing articles.
content: HONG KONG — A Hong Kong judge granted the pro-democracy media tycoon Jimmy Lai bail on Wednesday, but imposed extensive restrictions barring him from using social media, giving interviews or leaving his home, stoking concerns about the deterioration of free speech under a national security law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘It’s More Money Than I Imagined.’ So He’s Giving Some of It Away.
description: How Jeremy O. Harris has turned his good fortune into grants, commissions and donations to other playwrights, and to libraries in need.
content: Jeremy O. Harris is a playwright, a performer, and a provocateur. And now, he’s a philanthropist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: The Breakout Stars of 2020
description: Here are the 12 stars and trends that managed to thrive and shine in an impossible year.
content: While plenty of us felt trapped this year, wandering through the same spaces and talking to the same people, it was the artists and entertainers who kicked open windows to new sights, sounds and experiences. Yes, the pandemic dealt a significant hit to the culture world, but nothing could derail its creativity. So, despite the limitations, stars in a variety of disciplines managed to thrive and shine, and by doing so, made a difficult year more tolerable for most everyone. Here are 12 artists and trends who gave us a fresh perspective in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Pulse Oximeters May Be Less Accurate for Black People. Should You Use One?
description: Although a new study showed the technology is more error prone in people with darker skin, doctors say the device is still useful for anyone monitoring Covid-19 at home.
content: Home pulse oximeters have been the personal tech gadget of 2020 and a reassuring way for patients to monitor their health at home during Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Xin Xing, Giant Panda With Progeny Around the Globe, Dies at 38
description: The star of China’s Chongqing Zoo was the world’s oldest panda in captivity. More than 150 of her descendants have lived in several countries.
content: HONG KONG — Xin Xing, a giant panda who grew to an age that shattered records, lived a life of great appetites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: N.B.A. Postpones Rockets Game, an Early Test of the League’s Virus Rules
description: Multiple positive or inconclusive coronavirus tests, and a health protocol breach, left the Houston Rockets with too few players to compete in their season opener Wednesday.
content: In an immediate blow to the N.B.A.’s attempt to stage a season without the protection of a restricted-access bubble, league officials were forced to postpone the Houston Rockets’ season opener on Wednesday night against the Oklahoma City Thunder when the Rockets were unable to field the required minimum of eight players in uniform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Sameer Yasir and Tiffany May
title: Even after border reopens, truckers stuck at British ports scuffle with the police.
description: Britain agreed to broad virus tests for truck drivers as part of a deal to reopen land, air and sea routes to France.
content: After blocking freight traffic from Britain in an attempt to stop the spread of a possibly more contagious variant of the coronavirus, France reopened its border on Wednesday to truck transport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Wise and Lily Benson
title: The Wildest Animal News From 2020
description: These are the stories about birds, bugs, fish and mammals that surprised and delighted readers the most this year.
content: It was a rough year for Homo sapiens. The coronavirus pandemic highlighted our vulnerabilities in a natural world that is constantly changing. Many were pushed to find new levels of resolve and creativity to survive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronica Penney
title: Our Best Reporting of 2020
description: Also this week: Women on the front lines of climate activism
content: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: Ezra F. Vogel, Eminent Scholar of China and Japan, Dies at 90
description: A longtime scholar at Harvard, Professor Vogel wrote books that helped shape how the world viewed the two ascendant economic powers.
content: Ezra F. Vogel, an eminent scholar of East Asia at Harvard University whose writings about modern politics and society in China and Japan helped shape how the world understood the rise of those two Asian powers, died on Sunday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
title: Meet the People Who Can’t Bring You ‘Messiah’ This Year
description: Listen as nine performers guide you through the emotional arc of Handel’s classic, from comfort to grief to jubilation.
content: Every year, Handel’s “Messiah” is a communal ritual — a glittering parade of recitatives, arias and choruses that binds listeners and performers together in a story of promise, betrayal and redemption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: The Beauty Products That Got Us Through 2020
description: The year home became not just an office, but a salon and spa.
content: Unable to visit their hair stylists, aestheticians, hair braiders or nail technicians for much of this year, many people began D.I.Y.-ing their beauty routines. At-home haircuts and dye jobs boomed. Online shopping took center stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Four Charged Over Blaze That Devastated Australia’s Fraser Island
description: The police said the men started an illegal campfire, but experts said the region would remain vulnerable to more fires as climate change worsens dry conditions.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Four people have been charged with unlawfully lighting a campfire that the authorities said sparked huge blazes on Fraser Island off the northeastern coast of Australia in October, ultimately razing more than 210,000 acres of the popular vacation spot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arlene Dávila
title: A National Museum for Latinos
description: A monument highlighting our contributions may finally become reality.
content: On Monday, Congress authorized the creation of a Latino museum as part of a $2.3-trillion year-end spending bill. This is long overdue. For decades, activists have been fighting to establish a Latino museum on the Washington Mall. Its creation is essential to documenting the community’s contribution and to the education and future of all Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: As Evidence Mounts that Navalny Was Poisoned by State, Russians Just Sigh
description: Aleksei Navalny, the top critic of President Putin, has aired evidence that he was poisoned by his own government. Russians have responded with fear, disbelief and a lot of apathy.
content: MOSCOW — Vitaly Mansky, a filmmaker, posed in front of the headquarters of Russia’s domestic intelligence agency brandishing a pair of checkered blue boxers. He was immediately detained by the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Says He Cannot Quickly Undo Trump Border Policies
description: It will take time to rebuild capacity to enable asylum seekers to be processed, the president-elect and his aides say, and they warn of a rush to the border.
content: In a message intended to prevent a rush to the southwestern border, the incoming Biden administration announced on Tuesday that it would not immediately reverse restrictions imposed by President Trump that have effectively halted asylum and left thousands of migrants stranded outside the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Nadelson
title: The Department Store That Does Holiday Cheer Like No Other
description: With its fanciful window displays and winter grotto, Macy’s has long been synonymous with Christmas in New York.
content: In this series for T, the author Reggie Nadelson revisits New York institutions that have defined cool for decades, from time-honored restaurants to unsung dives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How We Survive Winter’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about how different people and cultures interpret and approach winter. Then they will express how they feel about winter using photography, drawing, poetry or storytelling.
content: Featured Article: “How We Survive Winter” by Elizabeth Dias
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Serves and Receives
description: Juliana Tringali Golden floats into our lives and makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — After finishing Amy Yanni and Jeff Chen’s joyous Tuesday puzzle, we float happily along to our midweek crossword, which also happens to be a debut by Juliana Tringali Golden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Trump Vetoes Military Spending Bill, Setting Up a Congressional Showdown
description: The legislation passed with a veto-proof majority in the House and Senate, but it is unclear whether Congress will override the president.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Wednesday made good on his promise to veto the annual military policy bill, setting up what could be the first veto override of his presidency after both chambers of Congress overwhelmingly approved the legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Chinese Swimmer’s Doping Ban Is Lifted After Accusation of Racism
description: Lawyers for Sun Yang, a three-time Olympic champion, presented evidence that one of the arbitrators who issued his eight-year suspension had made racist comments about China on social media.
content: Sun Yang, a three-time Olympic champion and one of China’s most celebrated athletes, had his eight-year ban from swimming suddenly overturned Wednesday by Switzerland’s federal court, which upheld a challenge questioning the neutrality of one of the panelists who had issued the penalty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Carey Mulligan Won’t Let Hollywood Off the Hook
description: The actress delivered the performance of her career in the dark comedy “Promising Young Woman.” Then came those with their tired views of women.
content: Not every Carey Mulligan movie begins with a Charli XCX song, but maybe more of them should. When “Promising Young Woman” deploys the 2017 pop bop “Boys” in its opening moments, it’s the first sign you’re about to get something from Mulligan that you’re not used to: namely, a contemporary setting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Indian airports are struggling with the ban on flights from Britain.
description: Passengers flying into India from Britain and other European countries said they spent hours waiting in lines at the airport over the past two days as the authorities struggled to implement new quarantine measures intended to counter the spread of a coronavirus variant that has emerged in Britain.
content: Passengers flying into India from Britain and other European countries said they spent hours waiting in lines at the airport over the past two days as the authorities struggled to implement new quarantine measures intended to counter the spread of a coronavirus variant that has emerged in Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: $1.25 Million Homes in California, Louisiana and Illinois
description: A sculptural concrete house in Santa Cruz County, an 1880 Victorian in New Orleans and a converted 19th-century fire station in Highland Park.
content: In 1972, Mary Gordon, a landscape architect, designed an organic concrete house near the beach in an unincorporated area of Santa Cruz County, which she intended to use as retirement quarters for herself and her husband. Constructed by boat builders — with tubular forms protruding from a rounded base, including a windowed cylinder emerging from the top like a periscope — the house ultimately became Ms. Gordon’s studio and a showplace for her gardening talents. Seven years ago, it was sold to a second owner, who made it homier by adding a stainless-steel spiral staircase inside and improving the kitchen and bathroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bianca Giaever
title: The Year in Good News
description: In a bleak year, our listeners offer some brightness — from all over the world.
content: The idea for this episode came in mid-November, when The Daily team received an email about the upcoming release of the hip-hop artist Megan Thee Stallion’s album “Good News.” It had been a wild year for Megan: She said she suffered gunshot wounds in July; months later, she appeared on Cardi B’s hit single “WAP.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: The Secret to Longevity? 4-Minute Bursts of Intense Exercise May Help
description: Including high-intensity training in your workouts provided better protection against premature death than moderate workouts alone.
content: If you increase your heart rate, will your life span follow?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Foo
title: Have Yourself a Lonely Little Christmas
description: I’ve spent many a holiday by myself. And you know what? It can be absolutely thrilling.
content: A few years ago, I lived across the street from a halfway house in the Lower East Side. Sometimes I’d meander over to bum cigarettes from the men who loitered outside, and we’d smoke and make small talk. One Christmas, I brought over a large cheesecake as a consolation gift: None of us were spending Christmas with our families, and none of us were thrilled about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Review: ‘Bridgerton’ Is a Sparkly Period Piece With a Difference
description: The first Netflix series from Shonda Rhimes’s company updates the genre with modern race and gender attitudes (and lots of skin).
content: Netflix’s “Bridgerton” begins like any other British period drama about the fancy folk. The sun shines on Grosvenor Square. Horses pull fine carriages along a resplendent street. A dapper gentleman out for a stroll nods his head to a passer-by.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: Walter Tevis Was a Novelist. You Might Know His Books (Much) Better as Movies.
description: In addition to “The Queen’s Gambit,” adapted into the current Netflix hit, Walter Tevis wrote the novels “The Hustler,” “The Color of Money” and “The Man Who Fell to Earth.”
content: The wildly popular Netflix series “The Queen’s Gambit” has done for chess what Julia Child once did for French cooking. Chess set sales have skyrocketed; enrollment in online chess classes has surged. The series has been the subject of hundreds of articles and interviews. The novel that inspired the show, first published in 1983, has been on The New York Times’s trade paperback best-seller list for five weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Our 2nd Annual STEM Writing Contest
description: We invite students to choose an issue or question in science, technology, engineering, math or health, then write an engaging 500-word explanation. Contest Dates: Jan. 19-March 2, 2021.
content: Note: Register for our live webinar on Jan. 14 on teaching informational writing with a STEM theme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Actors and Writers and Now, Congressional Lobbyists
description: Be an #ArtsHero started with a failed effort to extend unemployment benefits. It’s gone on to be a prime proponent of the message: Cultural work is labor.
content: Art is what binds us. It illuminates the human condition. It’s good for the soul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Trump Threw the Stimulus a Curveball
description: The president threatened to upend a hard-fought compromise, but he may not get what he wants.
content: Not even a day after lawmakers agreed on a $900 billion stimulus package, President Trump called it a “disgrace” and suggested that he might reject the heavily negotiated bill at the eleventh hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Passenger Who Had Medical Emergency on Flight Died of Covid-19, Coroner Says
description: The episode in Louisiana raised concerns about the risks travelers face, even with heightened safety precautions in place.
content: A coroner in Louisiana confirmed on Tuesday what some had feared: that the death last week of a 69-year-old man who experienced a medical emergency aboard a United Airlines flight bound for Los Angeles had been caused by Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aileen Jacobson
title: The Lower East Side: Where Historic Tenements Meet Glassy Towers
description: In recent years, the country’s ‘most famous immigrant neighborhood’ has welcomed new high-end development. But it still has an old-school vibe.
content: Richard Kimmel was drawn to the Lower East Side partly by “a lot of family history,” he said, including his great-grandmother, “who arrived at Ellis Island on the Fourth of July in 1890,” and made her way to the densely populated neighborhood that has long been a haven for immigrants of many origins, with Eastern European Jews predominating at the turn of the last century.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: France eases travel restrictions on the U.K.

title: Virginia Shackles, Painter of Vivid Scenery, Dies at 99
description: Ms. Shackles loved to paint cliffs and ocean scenes in the coastal city of Monterey, Calif. She died of from complications of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: At Home’s Best of 2020
description: What we watched, read, listened to and cooked this year.
content: Welcome. It’s the time of year when “best of” lists proliferate, when critics look back on the previous 12 months and select their favorite stuff. The Times’s critics’ 2020 lists are splendid; I’ve already tracked down most of Manohla Dargis’s film picks and a bunch of the best podcasts and have them all ready to go in my various queues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Clubhouse Makes Way for Influencers
description: Tech investors have warmed to the idea that being a content creator is a legitimate form of business.
content: Nearly every social media platform has turned its top users into stars: YouTubers, Viners, Dubsmashers, TikTokers, even LinkedIn influencers. Now, Clubhouse, an audio-only app that built its name with tech investors before expanding into entertainment, is trying to cultivate its own local celebrities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Jose Garcia, New Mexico Farmworker, Dies at 68
description: One of Mr. Garcia’s nine children, a nurse at the hospital in Las Cruces where he died, was the only family member allowed to visit with him as he battled Covid-19.

title: 5 Unforgettable Conversations From the Events Team
description: Whether they broke down the news or broke up the day, The Times’s live discussions, demonstrations and performances this year offered audiences something rare: a sense of connection.
content: After a year that so often kept people apart, the events staff at The New York Times wanted to take a moment to celebrate the occasions that brought us together.

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: Nobody Is Singing for This Kind of Christmas Storm
description: Forecasters predict blizzards in the Midwest. Freezing temperatures in the South. Flooding and power outages in the Northeast. And maybe tornadoes in Florida.
content: Children dream and carolers sing of white Christmases, but they’re not wishing for the kind of messy, potentially destructive winter storm that’s expected to sweep across the eastern half of the United States on Christmas Eve.

title: Police Took Their Son Away. Then the Merchants of Hope Showed Up.
description: The police seize and kill young men in Nigeria. Then pastors, lawyers and so-called human rights advocates squeeze money out of their families, promising to help find them.
content: AWKA, Nigeria — In the small family portrait gallery hanging above the television in the cozy home of the Iloanya family, only two framed photographs remain that include the youngest son, Chijioke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: 23 Are Rescued After Baltimore Building Explosion
description: The explosion happened on the 16th floor of the Baltimore Gas and Electric Company building. The cause was not immediately clear, but the utility said it was likely a construction accident.
content: Nearly two dozen people were rescued on Wednesday morning after an explosion in an office building in downtown Baltimore caused part of the structure’s roof to collapse, the authorities said.

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Pundit Accountability
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Americans under the age of 40 vote at relatively low rates. They also lean left politically. The same is true of Latinos and Asian-Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: As at-home rapid tests enter the market, remember that ‘negative’ doesn’t always mean negative.
description: Since the start of the pandemic, the Food and Drug Administration has issued emergency green lights to more than 200 types of coronavirus tests, each with its own curiosities and quirks. Yet we tend to talk about all of them in the same binary way, with identical terms: positive, negative, true, false.

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘The Midnight Sky’ Review: It’s the End of the World, in the Arctic
description: George Clooney takes on his biggest challenge, as both actor and director, yet: Saving humanity itself.
content: George Clooney turns off his movie-star charm for much of “The Midnight Sky,” a futuristic adventure he stars in and directed. He plays Augustine Lofthouse, a scientist who, as the movie begins — in 2049, “3 weeks after the event,” a deliberately vague onscreen text puts it — has lived to become something of a prophet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: Jack Lenor Larsen, Innovative Textile Designer, Dies at 93
description: He blended ancient techniques and modern technology to weave fabrics that are in the collections of MoMA and the Louvre, which gave him a one-man retrospective.
content: Jack Lenor Larsen, a textile designer who blended ancient techniques and modern technology to weave fabrics that enlivened postwar American homes and workplaces and in the process became an international presence, died on Tuesday at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jal Mehta
title: Make Schools More Human
description: The pandemic showed us that education was broken. It also showed us how to fix it.
content: If a measure of a society is how well it takes care of its young, the past nine months are a damning indictment of our nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Now Airing on the Local News in Tennessee: Ads for Georgia Candidates
description: Nearly $470 million is set to be spent on ads for the Georgia Senate runoff races. With the airwaves already saturated, the candidates are heading across state lines to seek any possible advantage.
content: The Georgia Senate runoffs are so awash in political cash that the ad wars are spilling into neighboring states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: New Signs of Economic Distress Emerge as Trump Imperils Aid Deal
description: A decline in consumer income and spending poses a further challenge to the recovery as jobless claims remain high and benefits approach a cutoff.
content: With the fate of a federal aid package suddenly thrown into doubt by President Trump, economic data on Wednesday showed why the help is so desperately needed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: How Pop and Jazz Wrapped Up the Past in 16 Boxed Sets
description: Reissues and deluxe editions of albums by PJ Harvey, Lil Peep, Charles Mingus and others provide fresh looks at familiar works, and the creative processes that birthed them.

author: By Amr Alfiky
title: How 5 New Yorkers Are Coping with Holidays Alone
description: For many in New York City, their pandemic-imposed loneliness has been even more pronounced during the holiday season.
content: On March 12, I took my last subway ride home from work. I was listening to John Cale’s “Dying on the Vine” while standing in the middle of a cramped car. I could feel tension in the air — a mix of fear and uncertainty. As New Yorkers retreated indoors, many struggled with a new kind of loneliness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Antibody treatments have shown promise, but tens of thousands of doses are sitting unused in hospital refrigerators.
content: When President Trump fell ill with the coronavirus over two months ago, he took an antibody cocktail, made by Regeneron, and later promoted the treatment as a “cure.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Isolation appears to have helped homeless populations avoid the worst of the pandemic.
description: Early in the pandemic, health officials were terrified that the virus would decimate America’s homeless populations, the half-million people who live in shelters or on the streets. Those same specialists now say they are relieved that street encampments and homeless shelters did not suffer the same devastation as nursing homes.

title: Want the Good Life? This Philosopher Suggests Learning From Cats
description: In “Feline Philosophy,” John Gray concedes that we “cannot know what it is like to be a cat,” but that doesn’t stop him from trying.
content: An uncertain fate awaits the most bracing and contrarian writers: Will the insights they offer still come across as stingingly original if the disillusion they so often recommend becomes commonplace?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Isolation Helps Homeless Population Escape Worst of Virus
description: Despite outbreaks in shelters and the prospect of more, the rates of infection among homeless populations are lower than feared.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Under a highway overpass in downtown Oakland, Camilla Everette sleeps on a couch, with a blue-and-white-striped summer parasol offering the only protection from the drops of rainwater that fall from the concrete above her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson, Jesse Green, Scott Heller, Laura Collins-Hughes and Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Advocating and Agitating, Connecting and Inventing
description: With their field rocked by unprecedented challenges in 2020, these people and groups — some notable, some new — stepped into the breach.
content: There are producers serving on committees. Performers signing petitions. Then there is Andrew Lloyd Webber, the most successful living musical theater composer, who offered his body in an effort to resuscitate his beloved industry. The 72-year-old Briton, whose hit list includes “Cats” and “The Phantom of the Opera,” in August joined a vaccine trial in England, taking a shot of the experimental drug in his left arm while wearing a “Save Our Stages” T-shirt. And he’s been a relentless champion of theater’s return: In July he hosted the first West End pandemic show at his Palladium Theater in London (“This is a rather sad sight,” he said as he looked at the socially distanced audience), and he continued to press forward, recently presenting a holiday pantomime show whose audience included Prince William and his family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: These Bacon and Eggs Practically Cook Themselves
description: A big holiday breakfast is great — unless you’re the one stuck making it. This sheet-pan recipe is the solution.
content: There’s a way to plates of crispy bacon and sunny-side-up eggs that doesn’t demand you stand over a hot skillet and get greasy. “Frying” bacon in a hot oven, then cooking eggs on the same sheet pan, turns out a meal for four in 15 minutes and requires almost no attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: A New Pinocchio Film Returns to the Tale’s Dark Origins
description: The Italian director Matteo Garrone hopes to surprise audiences this Christmas with a very literal retelling of the children’s classic.
content: ROME — Carlo Collodi’s “Pinocchio” is one of the world’s best-loved children’s books, translated into over 280 languages and dialects, and the subject of countless films and television series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah Engel Bromwich
title: The Evictions Are Coming. Housing Activists Are Ready.
description: Orders to halt evictions in New York expire soon. What happens next?
content: Housing activists in New York have spent much of the year preparing for the end of it. Tenant evictions have been halted or delayed by coronavirus relief measures, for the most part, until January 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leigh-Ann Jackson
title: The Workweek Diary of a Plant-Loving Home Décor Guru
description: Justina Blakeney preaches the gospel of infusing your home with good vibes, thoughtful intentions, and lots and lots of plants.
content: “The home is not a static place,” the home décor maven Justina Blakeney said, reflecting on the importance of design in our living spaces. “Your home needs to grow and change as you grow and change. It can support you, if you put your mind to it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sammi Katz and Olivia McGiff
title: Reclaiming the Tiki Bar
description: Tiki bars are a beverage industry mainstay — with a painful and underexamined past. Can the format be repaired?
content: It is an unquestionably difficult time for the hospitality industry. Every day, another restaurant shutters, one more bar pulls its steel gate down for good. Since its invention, one kind of watering hole has seen America through its most grueling times: the tiki bar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Will Trump Force Principled Conservatives to Start Their Own Party? I Hope So
description: American politics will be shaped by the influence of the monarch of Mar-a-Lago.
content: As the Trump presidency heads into the sunset, kicking and screaming, one of the most important questions that will shape American politics at the local, state and national levels is this: Can Donald Trump maintain his iron grip over the Republican Party when he is out of office?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: glut
description: This word has appeared in 186 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Salman Toor, a Painter at Home in Two Worlds
description: A brilliant debut at the Whitney Museum by the artist — born in Pakistan and based in New York — refreshes figurative painting by using it as a means to explore identity.
content: Salman Toor’s evocative, tenderly executed paintings begin to pluck at your heartstrings almost as soon as you see them. The 15 examples of new and recent work that form “How Will I Know,” the artist’s brilliant New York institutional debut at the Whitney Museum of American Art tell the stories of lanky, slightly rubbery dark-haired young men, gentle souls who wouldn’t hurt a flea. The narrative import zigzags from the personal to the social and political and back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: The Tech That Was Fixed in 2020 and the Tech That Still Needs Fixing
description: From videoconferencing to fitness apps, the best tech helped us endure a hard year. But there were also low points.
content: To put it lightly, 2020 was rough. More than ever, we turned to our personal tech this year to help find respite, stay healthy and remain connected with the people we care about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada approves the Moderna vaccine, paving the way for inoculations in its vast Far North.
description: Canada’s regulator approved Moderna’s vaccine on Wednesday, a move that will make it easier to inoculate people in the country’s remote and northern regions.
content: Canada’s regulator approved Moderna’s vaccine on Wednesday, a move that will make it easier to inoculate people in the country’s remote and northern regions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: A New Population of Blue Whales Was Discovered Hiding in the Indian Ocean
description: The whales in the group seem to sing a unique song.
content: Weighing up to 380,000 pounds and stretching some 100 feet long, the blue whale — the largest creature to have ever lived on Earth — might at first seem difficult for human eyes and ears to miss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Smith
title: ‘Blue’ Gene Tyranny, Whose Music Melded Genres, Dies at 75
description: A creator of modern music as a teenager, he later juggled a breezy pop sensibility with conceptual rigor. He was an important collaborator with the composer Robert Ashley.
content: Robert Sheff, a composer and pianist who worked under the name “Blue” Gene Tyranny as a solo performer and a collaborator with artists including Iggy Pop, the composer Robert Ashley and the jazz composer and arranger Carla Bley, died on Dec. 12 in hospice care in Long Island City, Queens. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Vauchok, Alex Marshall and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: This Band Is Fun on TikTok. In Belarus, It’s Serious.
description: Molchat Doma, a synth-pop trio, has become an unlikely social media star. Back home, its music was the soundtrack to a traumatic year.
content: MINSK, Belarus — On a recent Saturday night, Hide, a trendy nightclub in Belarus’s capital, was packed. More than 600 clubgoers were jostling for a view of the stage in the tiny venue, hidden in an inner-city courtyard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: 8 Fearless N.B.A. Season Predictions
description: Houston’s James Harden is widely expected to be traded soon. But Kevin Love? Zach LaVine? LaMarcus Aldridge? They could be on the move, too.
content: The N.B.A.’s 75th season began Tuesday night with wins by the Nets and the Clippers. A new calendar year arrives in just nine days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Horner
title: You Can Learn a Lot About Human Nature From Takeout Orders
description: In a world where everything was changing, the menu at a small New Orleans restaurant also had to adapt. Not everyone seemed to get that.
content: NEW ORLEANS — Opening a restaurant is hard. A lot of people will tell you it’s a bad idea. Especially in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Swanson
title: Escape the Room, Escape the World
description: A family takes refuge from life’s sharper edges by solving puzzles together.
content: On a warm Saturday evening, my 6-year-old drew invitations by hand and passed them out to his brother, his father and me. You are invited! Dress nice!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden Assails Trump Over Handling of Russia Hacking
description: “This assault happened on Donald Trump’s watch when he wasn’t watching,” President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. said.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. accused President Trump on Tuesday of “irrational downplaying” of the widespread hack of the federal government and American industries, saying that the current administration was denying him intelligence and warning Russia that he would not allow the intrusion to “go unanswered” after he takes office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Sugary Drinks May Be Bad for Aging
description: Consumption of both sugar-sweetened and artificially sweetened drinks was tied to an increased risk for frailty in women over 60.
content: Sweetened drinks are not generally considered healthy for anyone, but they may be particularly harmful for the elderly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Year the Fed Changed Forever
description: Jerome H. Powell’s central bank slashed rates, bought bonds in huge sums and rolled out never-before-tried loan programs that shifted its identity. The backlash is already beginning.
content: WASHINGTON — As Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, rang in 2020 in Florida, where he was celebrating his son’s wedding, his work life seemed to be entering a period of relative calm. President Trump’s public attacks on the central bank had eased up after 18 months of steady criticism, and the trade war with China seemed to be cooling, brightening the outlook for markets and the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: The Virus That Stole Most of 2020 Now Steals Christmas, Too
description: Across Italy and beyond, those who lost loved ones this year had looked forward to a holiday with the rest of their friends and relatives. But for many, it’s not to be.
content: ROME — This will be Rinaldo Verzeni’s first Christmas without his father.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2020 Popcast Listener Mailbag: Taylor, Dua, MGK and More
description: Answering your questions about the year’s biggest stars, and also some of its curious flops.
content: This wild, wildly disorienting year is coming to a close, and as usual, the Popcast opened up its listener mailbag to tackle the questions that have been keeping listeners up at night (when they’re not up at night listening to Popcast, that is).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Trump’s Team Eyes the Exits
description: Farewell, henchmen.
content: Oh, how the mighty have fallen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: Columbus Police Kill Black Man Weeks After Protests Against Brutality
description: “Our community is exhausted,” said the mayor of the Ohio capital, which is still reeling from the fatal shooting of Casey Goodson Jr.
content: A police officer fatally shot a Black man early Tuesday in Columbus, Ohio, three weeks after a county sheriff’s deputy killed a Black man in the state capital, which ignited a round of protests against police brutality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: 13 New Books to Watch For in January
description: Essays from Joan Didion, George Saunders on why fiction matters and plenty more.
content: If your days are feeling monotonous, you might find entertainment and variety in this flurry of new books about subjects that span the globe. A Danish writer’s collected memoirs trace her effort to nurture artistic ambition in spite of a grim family life and, later, addiction. A biography revisits the lives of two pioneering sisters who paved the way for women to practice medicine in the United States. And a debut novel imagines a romance between two enslaved men in Civil War-era Mississippi. No matter what you’re seeking, you can find it in the pages of a book next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Rebecca Luker, a Broadway Star for Three Decades, Dies at 59
description: Her Broadway career, fueled by her crystal-clear operatic soprano, brought her Tony Award nominations for “Show Boat,” “The Music Man” and “Mary Poppins.”
content: Rebecca Luker, the actress and singer who in a lauded three-decade career on the New York stage embodied the essence of the Broadway musical ingénue in hit revivals of “Show Boat,” “The Sound of Music” and “The Music Man,” died on Wednesday in a hospital in Manhattan. She was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Pulitzer Board Rescinds New York Times’s ‘Caliphate’ Citation
description: The podcast, which The Times now says did not meet its editorial standards, and a related report on ISIS had been named finalists in the 2019 international category.
content: The Pulitzer Prize Board said on Tuesday that it would no longer recognize the New York Times podcast “Caliphate” and a related article as a 2019 Pulitzer finalist. The board stripped The Times of its finalist status four days after the news organization announced that the 2018 audio series did not meet its standards for accuracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Shawn Hubler
title: Meet Alex Padilla, California’s Next Senator

content: Good morning.

author: By Rory Smith
title: European Soccer Learns a New Virtue: Patience
description: Why have so few managers been fired this year? Pandemic economics play a role, but there are bigger forces at work, too.
content: LONDON — Enrico Preziosi could hardly have held Thiago Motta in higher esteem. As a player, Motta spent only a single season at Genoa, the Italian soccer team Preziosi owns, but he made such an impression that, a decade later, his old boss cited him as his ideal professional. “A smart and empathetic man,” Preziosi said. “He taught me many things.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Corrupted the Presidential Pardon. Biden Must Repair It.
description: There are clear ways to reform the pardon process to work as the founders intended.
content: This editorial has been updated to reflect breaking news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Rappeport
title: Trump Demands Changes to Coronavirus Relief Bill, Calling It a ‘Disgrace’
description: The president sought bigger checks for Americans and a bill that dealt more specifically with pandemic relief.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Tuesday evening threatened to derail months of bipartisan work in Congress to deliver $900 billion in coronavirus relief to a country battered by the pandemic, demanding checks to Americans that are more than three times as much as those in the bill, which he called a “disgrace.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Cunningham
title: Michael Cunningham on Virginia Woolf’s Literary Revolution
description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist explains how Woolf turned an ordinary day in an ordinary life into a masterpiece.
content: Virginia Woolf’s “Mrs. Dalloway” is a revolutionary novel of profound scope and depth, about a day in the life of a woman who runs a few errands, sees an old suitor and gives a dull party. It’s a masterpiece created out of the humblest narrative materials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Why Israel Faces a Fourth Election in Just Two Years
description: What to know as Israel gears up for another vote, this time set for March 23.
content: JERUSALEM — With Israel heading to its fourth election in two years after the collapse of its government, many Israelis are wondering whether it’s a case of too much democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Trump Pardons Two Russia Inquiry Figures and Blackwater Guards
description: The pre-Christmas wave of 20 pardons and commutations are not likely to be the last before Mr. Trump leaves office on Jan. 20.
content: In an audacious pre-Christmas round of pardons, President Trump granted clemency on Tuesday to two people who pleaded guilty in the special counsel’s Russia inquiry, four Blackwater guards convicted in connection with the killing of Iraqi civilians and three corrupt former Republican members of Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: After 32 Years, Charges Are Filed in Kidnapping of 9-Year-Old Girl
description: Witnesses saw Michaela Garecht kidnapped in Northern California in 1988. This week the authorities charged an incarcerated man with murder during a kidnapping.
content: For more than 30 years, the kidnapping of a 9-year-old girl, Michaela Garecht, has remained a mystery in Northern California, a crime witnessed by only a few people, including a child who was her best friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: An Online Show that Runs and Runs (and Runs)
description: “Stars in the House,” a variety show and fund-raiser, started just after the Broadway shutdown. Some 250 episodes later, its creators won’t quit.
content: In late February, Seth Rudetsky and his husband, James Wesley, finished hosting a Broadway-themed cruise that meandered through the Eastern Caribbean with talent like Lillias White and Beth Leavel aboard. As Covid-19 fears grew, Rudetsky, a Sirius XM radio host, concert accompanist and comedy writer, flew to Scottsdale, Ariz., for a show with the singer Norm Lewis. Wesley soon joined him in Houston to host a political fund-raiser. That was on Thursday, March 12, the day that New York State announced that Broadway would shutter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Queens Republicans Under Fire for Maskless ‘Covid Conga Line’ Party
description: Footage of revelers dancing without masks at a Republican club’s holiday event has led to an investigation of the venue, a popular Italian restaurant.
content: More than a dozen people shimmied through a glitzy banquet room in Queens earlier this month, forming a conga line during a holiday party thrown by a local Republican club. Coronavirus cases were spiking around the country, and it was days before Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo closed indoor dining in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: More areas in England lock down over new variant.
content: Struggling to curb the spread of a potentially more infectious variant of the coronavirus, the British government on Wednesday ordered more sections of England to be placed under restrictive lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas and Rebecca Robbins
title: What to Know About the Covid Antibody Drugs That Could Help Many
description: Here’s information about who these therapies can help, how much they cost and how to find out if you can get them where you live.
content: Two new antibody treatments have shown promise in keeping high-risk Covid-19 patients out of the hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: How Trump Has Jeopardized Stimulus Relief
description: The president’s demand that Congress amend a giant coronavirus relief and government spending bill has raised the unexpected prospect that help may no longer be days away.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Tuesday unexpectedly threatened to reject a far-reaching, catchall spending package that includes $900 billion in coronavirus relief and funding for the government through Sept. 30. The threat in effect dropped a depth charge on the Republican Party, but beyond politics, the coming days will determine whether his actions actually deny or delay relief to struggling Americans and shut down the government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Falih Hassan and Jane Arraf
title: Blackwater’s Bullets Scarred Iraqis. Trump’s Pardon Renewed the Pain.
description: Iraqi witnesses against Blackwater guards were promised justice after a mass killing in Baghdad in 2007. ‘Today,’ one said, the bullets still in his leg, ‘they proved to me it was just theater.’
content: BAGHDAD, Iraq — Haider Ahmed Rabia was stuck in traffic in Baghdad 13 years ago when guards with the American security contractor Blackwater opened fire with machine guns and grenade launchers, killing or wounding at least 31 Iraqi civilians. He still carries some of those bullets in his legs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Torres
title: My Sister Moved Into a Nursing Home. This Year. During a Pandemic.
description: Even without a deadly virus, finding the right place for her felt like facing a slate of rotten choices.
content: I never imagined my sister, who has long had trouble with her mobility, would move to a nursing home in a global pandemic. At 37, she is relatively young. But this fall, she developed a serious infection that worsened her health problems. So I found myself shopping for a facility that can provide her with the care she needs to recover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: Overwhelmed by virus victims, a New York funeral home became a scene of ‘horrifying disrespect.’
description: Andrew T. Cleckley was the first funeral director in New York to have his license revoked over the way he handled the remains of pandemic victims.
content: Sharon Escobar paid a Brooklyn funeral home to tend to the remains of her father, Elisha Magosha, after he died from complications of Covid-19 in April.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Confident Can You Be in a Coronavirus Test?
description: Things like which kind of test it was, and the reason for taking it, should factor into how much credence to give a positive or negative result.
content: In mid-November, David Piegaro tested positive for the coronavirus. His results came too late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: George Clooney on ‘The Midnight Sky’ and Donald Trump
description: His new movie is on Netflix, but the actor-director says theaters won’t go away and Hollywood will be fine. He’s not so sure about Washington.
content: In the Zoom era, the room behind you can really tell a story, and so it goes with George Clooney. On a recent video call to talk about his new Netflix movie, “The Midnight Sky,” Clooney gestured to the living room shelves behind him, which had been hastily stocked with books and booze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman, Elizabeth Paton, Jessica Testa and Guy Trebay
title: The Ups and Downs of Fashion in 2020
description: What happened in 2020, when everyone’s life (and wardrobe) was turned upside down.
content: It is a truth generally acknowledged that 2020 will be known as the year that changed everything: our attitude toward our health, technology and the fragility of democracy; the economies of the arts, hospitality, sports and travel.
source.name: The New York Times

description: What musicians would you include on your “best ever” playlist?
content: What songs do you consider to be among the greatest of all time? Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michaela Trimble
title: The Hotels Reimagining Their Rooms as Stylish Work Spaces
description: Throughout the pandemic, the hospitality industry has found new ways to attract and serve guests — including providing them with a desk for the day.
content: For some people fortunate enough to be working from home during the pandemic, forgoing a commute and sending emails from the living room has been a surprisingly welcome adjustment. For others — especially those sharing small spaces with loved ones — not so much. Where can you take a call when every room in your home is occupied by another family member, when a pipe bursts or when deafening jackhammering begins outside your window? Hotels, which have been hit hard during this time of social distancing and travel restrictions, have in recent months begun offering a possible solution, repositioning their rooms — in some instances by actually swapping out beds for luxurious desks and comfortable chairs — as picturesque offices in which to work in peace for a reduced day rate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Modern Love Podcast: What the Silence Said
description: Two marriages dissolve without a sound.
content: When Laura Pritchett and her husband divorced after two decades of marriage, their “little Colorado mountain town” could barely tell. It was quiet compared to the dramatic natural disasters that were afflicting the area — like flooding and wildfires. There were no raised voices, no feelings of fury.
source.name: The New York Times

description: The $900 billion stimulus bill passed by Congress this week is meant to address the needs of millions of Americans who have weathered the effects of the coronavirus pandemic for months, even as many federal programs to provide aid ran thin or expired.

author: By David Reich and Orlando Patterson
title: Ancient DNA Is Changing How We Think About the Caribbean
description: New research delivers surprising findings about Indigenous people in the region before contact with Europeans.
content: In 1492, Christopher Columbus touched land for the first time in the Americas, reaching the Bahamas, Hispaniola (present-day Dominican Republic and Haiti) and eastern Cuba. After he returned to Spain he reported that he had encountered islands rich in gold. A few years later his brother Bartholomew, who also traveled to the Americas, reported that Hispaniola had a large population whose labor and land could be put to the advantage of the Spanish crown. He estimated the population at 1.1 million people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Moms on the Frontlines
description: Health care workers are still fighting to keep their homes and communities safe.
content: When I spoke to Dr. Stephanie Whitener, 41, an anesthesia critical care physician and mother of two, the parent-teacher organization at her son’s elementary school was planning an in-person happy hour for teachers. “I spent yesterday trying to rally all the parents I knew in health care to stop it, because of the risk to them, and also to in-person learning,” said Dr. Whitener, who lives in Charleston, S.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Amar’e Stoudemire Is a Coach Now. But Don’t Call Him That.
description: Stoudemire has reunited with his Phoenix Suns cohort of Steve Nash and Mike D’Antoni on the Nets’ staff. It’s weird to him, too.
content: As recently as late July, Amar’e Stoudemire was seemingly as far away as possible from joining the Nets’ coaching staff and a high-wattage reunion of Phoenix Suns alumni in Brooklyn. Stoudemire was still playing abroad — and helping Maccabi Tel Aviv win a 54th league championship in Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Eshe Nelson and Jenny Gross
title: U.K. Tightens Restrictions as Alarm About Virus Variant Grows
description: British officials said severely curtailing human contact was the only way to protect people. Efforts to restart trade stalled, with more than 5,000 trucks stuck at English ports.
content: LONDON — The British authorities put even more areas of England under the tightest restrictions on Wednesday as officials struggled to slow the spread of a coronavirus variant that is potentially more infectious than those that have already wreaked havoc around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Dana Rubinstein
title: They Fueled A.O.C.’s Win. Can They Shape the N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race?
description: It’s not yet clear if voters want bold ideas from the left or a leader who can manage the city out of a crisis. Or maybe they want both.
content: Last summer, the rising influence of the Democratic Party’s progressive wing in New York seemed almost boundless.

author: By Aaron Randle
title: The Insanity, and Social Necessity, of Sports This Year
description: Despite its risks, watching pro sports has given so many of us a needed reprieve.
content: In late March, my uncle died unexpectedly. Phillip Randle was my dad’s little brother and his best friend. The loss, exacerbated by our inability to hold a funeral for him because of the pandemic, shrouded my father in a blanket of grief. I heard him weep for the second time in my life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Jesse Drucker and Rebecca R. Ruiz
title: Buried in Pandemic Aid Bill: Billions to Soothe the Richest
description: The voluminous coronavirus relief and spending bill that blasted through Congress on Monday includes provisions — good, bad and just plain strange — that few lawmakers got to read.
content: WASHINGTON — Tucked away in the 5,593-page spending bill that Congress rushed through on Monday night is a provision that some tax experts call a $200 billion giveaway to the rich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Gillian Friedman
title: For Millions of Jobless, Christmas Is a Season to Endure, Not Celebrate
description: Even with the prospect of new federal aid, many Americans face a holiday of tough choices, trying to celebrate while dealing with pressing needs.
content: Nicole Craig, an unemployed mother of two from Pittsburgh, will have no Christmas gifts for her two children, and the ham she bought with food stamps will be far less than their usual holiday dinner. Months behind on her rent and utility bills, she has been struggling to afford formula and diapers. But there is one thing she couldn’t give up: a small Christmas tree and the trimmings to go with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: 5 Die in ‘Catastrophic’ Crash That Splits Car in Half
description: Four recent high school graduates from Yonkers, N.Y., were killed when a speeding driver collided with their car.

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Does Your Dog Have Diabetes? You May Be at Higher Risk of Diabetes, Too
description: People with diabetic dogs were 32 percent more likely to develop Type 2 diabetes than those with healthy dogs. Cat owners showed no such link.
content: If your dog has diabetes, you may be at higher risk of developing the disease yourself. Those are the findings of a new study in BMJ that examined pet insurance data in Sweden along with medical records from the Swedish National Patient Register.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: 3 Police Officers in France Are Killed After Responding to Domestic Abuse Report
description: The officers were shot in an isolated hamlet in central France, the authorities said. The gunman, a heavily armed survivalist, was later found dead.
content: PARIS — A heavily armed gunman in central France killed three police officers responding early Wednesday to reports of domestic abuse, in a rare outburst of deadly violence against French security forces that a local prosecutor described as a “war scene.” The gunman was later found dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: ‘Fertility Is a Team Sport’: Father’s Health Tied to Pregnancy Loss
description: Conditions like hypertension, high cholesterol, obesity and diabetes in a father may affect whether a pregnancy reaches full term.
content: A father’s poor health before conception may increase the risk for pregnancy loss, a new study suggests.
source.name: The New York Times
